description.narrative: AWYAD will implement a protection integrated project in education in its established school called Progressive primary school, andother 5 neighbourig primary schools in zone 5 and 6 in refugee settlement of Palabek in Lamwo district. The project will use AWYAD#s proven integrated child protection model to deliver essential, equitable, access to education and protection for 3000 children. Asa reknown local organisation with a community based approach, AWYAD will involve the community in the promotion of peaceful-co exitance, child protection and advocating for the right to education to enhance increased enrollment and retantion of children in schooland increased social cohesion among refugees and hosts. AWYAD will organise Gender and Rights Protection training and awareness including child protection and peaceful-co existence activities including: # Coducting 2-day training in 4 schools for teachers, School Maangement Committees and PTAs on SGBV, child protection and safegurding as well as Prevention of Sexual Abuse and Exploitation # Training community Child Protection Committiees (CPCs) on Prevention of Sexual Exploitation and Abuse, child protection and safegurding for 2 days # Establishing community SGBV information billboards # Conductingcommunity awareness sessions on SGBV, PSEA and Child rights using SASA and MDD. # Providing Music, Dance and Drama kits to schools to promote recreation, social cohesion and peacefulco-existance # Providing sports kits to schools to facilite children'sparticipation in sports to promote recreation, social cohesion and peaceful co-existance # Conducting school peace debates and community peace dialogues # Providing 400 extremely vulnerable girls from 5 schools with menstral hygiene kits to ensure theirmenstraul protection and dignity. # Organizing girl mentorship and coaching sessions in schools

participating-org.narrative: African Women and Youth Action for Development (AWYAD) is a Non-Government Organization (NGO) founded by Christians with a deep concern for vulnerable youth and women in Uganda, South Sudan, Kenya and Tanzania in the East African Region, living in abjectpoverty and whose voices cannot be heard. AWYAD was established 2010, by Christians with a passion to support vulnerable youth and women groups in various parts of the region, where 78% of youth are enslaved in the war of want, unintended self-torture, unproductiveness, crime, hunger and stress due to poverty as a result of joblessness and hopelessness. Over 70% of women in many rural communities live through untold suffering caused by horror of poverty associated with cultural and economic injustices such as discrimination and unpaid labour which is both on and off farm. During emergencies like sever famine and hunger and displacement, women and children suffer most from the consequences of the disaster. In order to overcome these challenges, AWYAD isdriven with a passion to work and advocate for change that eradicates the causes of poverty, discrimination and injustice striving to achieve equality, voice and empowerment. The organization targets vulnerable youth between the age of 15 <(>&<)> 30 years andvulnerable women including young single mothers, widows, women with HIV and disability with competitive skills and knowledge on agro business, promoting talent, innovation andentrepreneurship as well as nurturing and mentoring youth and women leaders withskills to influence, participate in decision makingfor the development of their families, their communities and nation.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to life and security
